attributes.title: The Role of Poverty Psychology in Healthier Diets: An application to the Willingness to Pay for Healthy Packaged Bread in the Mexico City Area

q1.value: The Role of Poverty Psychology in Healthier Diets: An application to the Willingness to Pay for Healthy Packaged Bread in the Mexico City Area

q2.value: Marcos Esau Dominguez Viera | Marrit van den Berg

q5.value: Sources of funding: This work is financially supported by the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT). Conflicts of interest: There are no potential conflicts of interest on the part of either of the authors., Ethics: This research is following the ethical clearance procedure by Wageningen University and Research’s Social Sciences Ethics Committee.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Traditional barriers for healthy eating are mostly availability, affordability and knowledge. Complementarily, poverty-related cognitive load and stress negatively may influence the demand for healthier foods, for instance, because individuals are more prone to neglect nutrition and health information, thereby representing a self-control issue. We take healthier packaged bread as case study in the of Mexico City area. A lab-in-the-field BDM auction experiment is implemented, where we will measure the willingness to pay for two healthier bread varieties. Such theories and methods are applied for the first time to study the demand for healthier processed foods in a developing urban-poor context.

q16.value: Hypothesis: H1) in the absence of the nutrition information, WTP for healthy bread is below its market price; H2) when poverty-related cognitive load and stress are induced the WTP for the healthy bread decreases; H3) in the absence of induced poverty-related cognitive load and stress, nutrition information increases WTP for the healthier bread option; H4) when poverty-related cognitive load and stress are induced, the effect of nutrition information on WTP for the healthier bread option decreases. The primary outcome of the study is the estimated willingness to pay for the healthier bread varieties. Secondary outcomes are perceived stress and cognitive load.

q17.value: We implement a BDM-auction to estimate the willingness to pay for two healthier bread varieties. In addition, this experiment has a 2x2 factorial design (see table below) with two treatments: 1) poverty priming and nutrition/health information. Treatment Nutrition/Health information Yes No Poverty-priming Hard condition Group 1 Group 2 Easy condition Group 3 Group 4 For H1, we compare average willingness to pay in Groups 2 and 4 with market prices. Regarding H2 we will compare groups in the first row with those in the second row. Then, for H3 we will compare groups 3 and 4, whereas for H4, we will compare groups 1 and 3.

q23.value: Research design was submitted to ethical approval with the Wageningen University and Research’s Social Sciences Ethics Committee. Formal approval expected soon.

q27.value: Researchers, The experiment is implemented by the researchers with funding and coordination with CIMMYT’s staff.

attributes.title: How To Make Voters Read More Hard News? Evidence from a Factorial App Experiment in Italy

q1.value: How To Make Voters Read More Hard News? Evidence from a Factorial App Experiment in Italy

q5.value: Support from NYU Politics is greatly appreciated.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: News represent the primary source of political information. How do voters choose what to read? This paper implements an experiment to measure individual demand for news and identify which factors affect voters’ media diets online. I develop a mobile app, Dossier, that collects real news from all national newspapers in Italy. Initially, the same mix of content is delivered to each participant and I collect frequency in their access to the app (extensive margin), individual news choices and reading time (intensive margin). Secondly, I manipulate the mix of news between soft and hard news that users receive to test how incentives to consume news are affected by content.

q16.value: The primary test that this experiment will perform will be on how experimental variation in media content affects readership of hard news. We expect to find that the more distractive the environment is the less the learning. This will be induced by two treatments: one based on a reduction in readership of hard news due to the competition with soft news; secondly it will be measured by the reduced opportunity for reading hard news as measured, in the concentration of hard to soft news. This leads to the following hypothesis: Hypothesis 1: Increases in soft news coverage reduces hard news consumption. The second group of hypothesis concerns the implied effect that consumption has on polit- ical issues and it will be implied by both the concentration and positioning treatment. I expect to find that the reduction in readership leads to a reduction in interest in politics and a shifting on important issues toward more radical positions. Hypothesis 2: Decreases in hard news readership reduces interest in politics and political knowledge.

q17.value: In order to test how the design of information online affects viewers readership and involve- ment in the political process, this experiment will employ the use of a highly factorial design. The results will be able to show what is the best combination of factors that induces higher read- ership. We will manipulate: Access - content: percentage of soft and hard news into 5 scale increments (20, 40, 50, 60, 80 percent); - Notifications ( 2 conditions); Consumption - positioning of soft/hard news: separated or mixed together next to hard news (2 conditions); - headlines or previews ( 2 conditions); - presence of images ( 2 conditions); These different conditions amount to a 4 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 factorial design that would allow us to investigate how the interaction of these different features affect user experience and how that impact his political engagement and knowledge. The app will collect real-time news based on RSS feed of all national daily newspapers a provide them to the user in an organized manner. The central server will collect all the news available in real time and deliver them through the app. The news feed will update each time the user enters the app. The ranking of the stories will not be based on editorial choices but date, more recent stories will come first. The experiment will provide two central contributions. First will test the effect that new technologies have in experiencing information in general, and specifically, political information. Secondly, will enable a very granular analysis of the behavior of voters with technology and to assess which voters are more susceptible to be affected by these strategies.

attributes.title: The Political Economy of Elections in Lagos

q1.value: The Political Economy of Elections in Lagos

q2.value: Leonardo Arriola | Shelby Grossman | Andrew Miller

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The current literature on electoral violence overlooks the fact that individuals in many developing countries are embedded in clientelistic relationships that regulate their participation in politics as well as their access to resources (Scott 1969; Piattoni 2001). These clientelistic relationships — the personalized networks that facilitate the mutually beneficial exchange of material benefits for political support — are known to shape the behavior of both politicians and voters (Kitschelt and Wilkinson 2007). But the role of clientelistic relationships in mediating individual experiences with electoral violence has been neither theoretically developed nor empirically tested. In this context, the proposed research contributes to our understanding of electoral violence in two ways. First, we examine whether individuals who belong to clientelistic-like associations are exposed to electoral violence at different rates or in different forms. Second, we examine how exposure to violence affects individual attitudes and behaviors toward politics. To pursue such questions, we focus on the experiences of traders in Lagos, the commercial capital of Nigeria that is often affected by violence during local and national election campaigns. We study traders in particular because they are enmeshed in economic and political relationships that allow us to directly assess how clientelism affects their exposure to violence as well as how such exposure influences their subsequent behavior. Traders in Lagos often participate in market associations whose leaders provide clientelistic-like services with varying degrees of success in shielding them from official predation (Grossman 2016). In leveraging the variation in market associations, we seek to assess whether traders in associations with stronger leaders are less likely to be victimized by election violence.

q16.value: To examine if clientelistic relationships affect how traders experience electoral violence, we draw on Grossman’s (2016) finding that traders’ interactions with government officials are significantly mediated by their ties to market leaders. The influence of these market leaders extends to the political arena, allowing them to mobilize support among their members for politicians competing for local offices. We thus expect that the type of market association to which traders belong (strong vs. weak or engaged vs. disengaged) will significantly affect whether or how traders experience violence or other forms of electoral malfeasance during elections. We therefore examine the following hypotheses: H1: Traders under a market association (compared to traders who are not under an association) are more likely to have interactions with vote brokers in their commercial area. H2: Traders under strong associations (compared to traders under weak associations) are less likely to report experiencing or witnessing election violence or intimidation. H3: Traders under politically engaged associations (compared to traders under politically dis-engaged associations) are more likely to have interactions with vote brokers in their commercial area. Additionally, we examine respondents’ political attitudes and behaviors after being presented with a prompt reminding them about the possibility of election violence in Lagos. H4: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are more likely to fear becoming a victim of violence or political intimidation. H5: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are more likely to agree that vote monitoring is likely. H6: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are more likely to justify use of violence. H7: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are less likely to plan to vote in upcoming elections. H8: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are less likely to say they intend to vote for the local ruling party. H9: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are less likely to trust electoral institutions. For hypotheses H4-H9, we expect heterogeneous treatment effects based on market association membership as well as partisanship. The effect of the violence prompt should be weaker among members of strong or engaged market associations if they feel that their market leaders can insulate them from the violence in the first place. Similarly, members of the local ruling party should be less affected by the violence prompt if they expect to be shielded from violence otherwise directed at opposition supporters or swing voters.

q17.value: We will pursue two strategies for the empirical analyses. First, the analyses of H1-H3 will be conducted using linear regression. These analyses will use the self-reported measures of association strength and engagement. All regressions will be estimated without control variables as well as the following controls: income, party affiliation, ethnicity, and gender. We will employ commercial area fixed effects. Second, the analyses of H4-H9 will compare average responses among respondents randomly assigned to treatment and control conditions using standard two-sided difference-in-means tests with an alpha of 0.05. We will also estimate treatment effects by regressing the outcomes on the treatment condition along with the measures for heterogeneous effects, namely, market association type and party affiliation. Other controls will include income, ethnicity, and gender. We will also employ commercial area fixed effects in these analyses.

registration_responses.q1: The Political Economy of Elections in Lagos
registration_responses.q2: Leonardo Arriola | Shelby Grossman | Andrew Miller
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: The current literature on electoral violence overlooks the fact that individuals in many developing countries are embedded in clientelistic relationships that regulate their participation in politics as well as their access to resources (Scott 1969; Piattoni 2001). These clientelistic relationships — the personalized networks that facilitate the mutually beneficial exchange of material benefits for political support — are known to shape the behavior of both politicians and voters (Kitschelt and Wilkinson 2007). But the role of clientelistic relationships in mediating individual experiences with electoral violence has been neither theoretically developed nor empirically tested. In this context, the proposed research contributes to our understanding of electoral violence in two ways. First, we examine whether individuals who belong to clientelistic-like associations are exposed to electoral violence at different rates or in different forms. Second, we examine how exposure to violence affects individual attitudes and behaviors toward politics. To pursue such questions, we focus on the experiences of traders in Lagos, the commercial capital of Nigeria that is often affected by violence during local and national election campaigns. We study traders in particular because they are enmeshed in economic and political relationships that allow us to directly assess how clientelism affects their exposure to violence as well as how such exposure influences their subsequent behavior. Traders in Lagos often participate in market associations whose leaders provide clientelistic-like services with varying degrees of success in shielding them from official predation (Grossman 2016). In leveraging the variation in market associations, we seek to assess whether traders in associations with stronger leaders are less likely to be victimized by election violence.
registration_responses.q16: To examine if clientelistic relationships affect how traders experience electoral violence, we draw on Grossman’s (2016) finding that traders’ interactions with government officials are significantly mediated by their ties to market leaders. The influence of these market leaders extends to the political arena, allowing them to mobilize support among their members for politicians competing for local offices. We therefore examine the following hypotheses: H1: Traders under a market association (compared to traders who are not under an association) are more likely to have interactions with vote brokers in their commercial area. H2: Traders under strong associations (compared to traders under weak associations) are less likely to report experiencing or witnessing election violence or intimidation. H3: Traders under politically engaged associations (compared to traders under politically dis-engaged associations) are more likely to have interactions with vote brokers in their commercial area. Additionally, we examine respondents’ political attitudes and behaviors after being presented with a prompt reminding them about the possibility of election violence in Lagos. H4: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are more likely to fear becoming a victim of violence or political intimidation. H5: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are more likely to agree that vote monitoring is likely. H6: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are more likely to justify use of violence. H7: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are less likely to plan to vote in upcoming elections. H8: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are less likely to say they intend to vote for the local ruling party. H9: Respondents who receive the violence prompt are less likely to trust electoral institutions. For hypotheses H4-H9, we expect heterogeneous treatment effects based on market association membership as well as partisanship. The effect of the violence prompt should be weaker among members of strong or engaged market associations if they feel that their market leaders can insulate them from the violence in the first place. Similarly, members of the local ruling party should be less affected by the violence prompt if they expect to be shielded from violence otherwise directed at opposition supporters or swing voters.
registration_responses.q17: We will pursue two strategies for the empirical analyses. First, the analyses of H1-H3 will be conducted using linear regression. These analyses will use the self-reported measures of association strength and engagement. All regressions will be estimated without control variables as well as the following controls: income, party affiliation, ethnicity, and gender. We will employ commercial area fixed effects. Second, the analyses of H4-H9 will compare average responses among respondents randomly assigned to treatment and control conditions using standard two-sided difference-in-means tests with an alpha of 0.05. We will also estimate treatment effects by regressing the outcomes on the treatment condition along with the measures for heterogeneous effects, namely, market association type and party affiliation. Other controls will include income, ethnicity, and gender. We will also employ commercial area fixed effects in these analyses.

attributes.title: Winning Prospects and Changing Preferences on the Powers of the Executive: Evidence from the Transition to Super-Presidentialism in Turkey

q1.value: Winning Prospects and Changing Preferences on the Powers of the Executive: Evidence from the Transition to Super-Presidentialism in Turkey

q2.value: Aytug Sasmaz | Alper Yagci | Daniel Ziblatt

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: On June 24, 2018, Turkey will have its first presidential and parliamentary elections after the April 2017 constitutional referendum. In that referendum, voters voted a far-reaching constitutional amendment which foresaw a transition to what analysts have called a super-presidential system (Fish 2005) with broadened and largely unchecked powers for the popularly elected president from the parliamentary system. The amendment was accepted by 51% of valid votes, showing that 49% of voters, mostly voters of the anti AKP opposition, opted for the continuation of the parliamentary system. The upcoming elections on June 24 will complete this transition to the super-presidential system. For long, the expectation was that Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the current president of Turkey, would comfortably win these elections and become the first president of Turkey with broadened and largely unchecked executive powers, furthering the democratic backsliding in the country. Unexpectedly, though, in the runup to the elections, the opposition parties and politicians seemed to mobilize excited crowds and stood a plausible chance to win the presidential election. In this context, a key empirical question with wide ranging theoretical implications is: Given the possibility that an electoral victory might provide opposition parties with access to unconstrained powers of the presidency, would opposition voters (who had voted “No” in April 2017 referendum) now shift their position to support, in principle, the super-presidential system? Would their endorsement for this non-democratic system become more likely if they thought their candidate will win the elections? In short, are voters “contingent democrats”?

q16.value: We predict that all else equal, the prospect of victory for a voter’s partisan opponent would decrease support for a winner-take-all super-presidentialism, and, conversely, a higher prospect of winning for one’s own side would increase support for it. This basic mechanism may be conditional on two additional factors: First, existing wisdom suggests that social polarization is running deep in Turkish politics, and both sides, as a result, have an intense fear that the stakes are higher than “normal politics” and that the other side will impose its “way of life” on the country if it gets the opportunity. Secondly, existing wisdom suggests that Turkish voters express confidence in incumbent Erdogan’s ability to manage the economy compared to alternative leaders, even if they do not vote for him. Therefore we expect that system preferences may change due to winning prospects in interaction with the voters’ social distance to the other side, or in interaction with perceptions of how a change would affect the economy. Each expectation may be confirmed for all voters, or alternatively for one side only.

q17.value: Above hypotheses will be tested in a survey experiment that will be conducted with a representative sample in Istanbul, Turkey, before the first presidential and parliamentary elections for the new super-presidential system. In the survey experiment, the respondents will be first asked how they voted in the last parliamentary elections and in the last referendum to diagnose whether the voter is pro-government or pro-opposition. Voters who voted “Yes” in the last referendum will be assumed to be pro-government voters, whereas voters who voted “No” will be diagnosed as pro-opposition. Respondents will also be asked about their expectation on the results of the elections before the priming treatment. In the experiment embedded in the survey, the respondents will be randomly assigned to two treatments in which latest poll results are cited by the enumerator. Half of the respondents will be primed in a way that they will think that it is highly probable that the opposition will win the upcoming presidential elections (Treatment 1), and the other half will be primed to think that the government will win (Treatment 2). While citing the latest poll results, the enumerator will cite the names of pro-government and pro-opposition TV channels to those who have voted “Yes” and “No” for the 2017 referendum respectively, to enhance the credibility of the treatment.After the treatment, the respondents will be asked questions about their preference on whether the newly elected president should use the broad powers of a super-president and for the institutional design of the government (whether they support a return to a parliamentary system or endorse the new super-presidential system) and their justifications for this preference.

registration_responses.q1: Winning Prospects and Changing Preferences on the Powers of the Executive: Evidence from the Transition to Super-Presidentialism in Turkey
registration_responses.q2: Aytug Sasmaz | Alper Yagci | Daniel Ziblatt

The amendment was accepted by 51% of valid votes, showing that 49% of voters, mostly voters of the anti AKP opposition, opted for the continuation of the parliamentary system. The upcoming elections on June 24 will complete this transition to the super-presidential system. attributes.title: The Professionalism Advantage: Attracting, Fostering, or Retaining Quality?

q1.value: The Professionalism Advantage: Attracting, Fostering, or Retaining Quality?

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q16.value: Attracting Quality Hypothesis: Professional legislatures attract candidates who are of higher quality. Fostering Quality Hypothesis: Resources allow incumbents to increase in quality over time. Legislators with more resources increase in quality more quickly. Retaining Incumbents Hypothesis: Professional legislatures are more likely to retain incumbents because it is a more attractive position.

q17.value: In order to carry out the empirical tests we will use data from the 2014 National Candidate Survey (Broockman and Skovron 2018). See pre-analysis plan for more details.

registration_responses.q1: The Professionalism Advantage: Attracting, Fostering, or Retaining Quality?
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q16: Attracting Quality Hypothesis: Professional legislatures attract candidates who are of higher quality. Fostering Quality Hypothesis: Resources allow incumbents to increase in quality over time. Legislators with more resources increase in quality more quickly. Retaining Incumbents Hypothesis: Professional legislatures are more likely to retain incumbents because it is a more attractive position.

attributes.title: The exit-voice trade-off and the decline of public services

q1.value: The exit-voice trade-off and the decline of public services

q5.value: We thank University College London and University of Exeter for funding. We are grateful to Survation, which is commissioned to carry out the study, for advice on the design, in particular to Marius Mosoreanu and Chris Hopkins

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Hirschman’s exit, voice, and loyalty model, as set out in his eponymous book, poses a negative trade off between voice and exit. When citizens or consumers have more exit options they will less inclined to voice, taking advantage of exit to realize their preferences. Most tests are observational, suggesting the current experiment. This uses a survey-based approach, presenting respondents with scenarios to examine their voice and exit options. The example respondents are thinking about is health services in the UK, the location for the study. Respondents are given the scenarios of no choice of local health service practitioner (GP) (T1), some choice of GP (T2), and five choices of GP (T3).

q16.value: Randomisation: Groups T1 = no choice, T2= one of two, T3 = one of five GPS H1: When experiencing service failure, respondents will voice to the extent they experience lack of choice (simplified Hirschman) T1>T2>T3 H2: When experiencing service failure, respondents with no choice will voice less than those who have limited choice, while respondents who experience a wider range of choices will voice less than those who have limited choice (full Hirschman) T1T3 H3: The reduction in voice in response to exit options is greater for collective voice (with other patients) than individual voice in all conditions (except for T1 comparison with T2 in H2) H4A: Prior length of time with an actual GP (loyalty) reduces the effect of the choice option on voice (as a moderator in H1 and H2). H4B: Lower switching behaviour in other contexts (general loyalty) reduces the effect of the choice option on voice (as a moderator in H1 and H2) H5: The perceived effectiveness of voice will increase the greater the exit options that are available T1

q17.value: Two-sided t-tests OLS regression with and without covariates (see PAP)

registration_responses.q1: The exit-voice trade-off and the decline of public services
registration_responses.q5: We thank University College London and University of Exeter for funding. We are grateful to Survation, which is commissioned to carry out the study, for advice on the design, in particular to Marius Mosoreanu and Chris Hopkins
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Hirschman’s exit, voice, and loyalty model, as set out in his eponymous book, poses a negative trade off between voice and exit. When citizens or consumers have more exit options they will less inclined to voice, taking advantage of exit to realize their preferences. Most tests are observational, suggesting the current experiment. This uses a survey-based approach, presenting respondents with scenarios to examine their voice and exit options. The example respondents are thinking about is health services in the UK, the location for the study. Respondents are given the scenarios of no choice of local health service practitioner (GP) (T1), some choice of GP (T2), and five choices of GP (T3).
registration_responses.q16: Randomisation: Groups T1 = no choice, T2= one of two, T3 = one of five GPS H1: When experiencing service failure, respondents will voice to the extent they experience lack of choice (simplified Hirschman) T1>T2>T3 H2: When experiencing service failure, respondents with no choice will voice less than those who have limited choice, while respondents who experience a wider range of choices will voice less than those who have limited choice (full Hirschman) T1T3 H3: The reduction in voice in response to exit options is greater for collective voice (with other patients) than individual voice in all conditions (except for T1 comparison with T2 in H2) H4A: Prior length of time with an actual GP (loyalty) reduces the effect of the choice option on voice (as a moderator in H1 and H2). H4B: Lower switching behaviour in other contexts (general loyalty) reduces the effect of the choice option on voice (as a moderator in H1 and H2) H5: The perceived effectiveness of voice will increase the greater the exit options that are available T1
registration_responses.q17: Two-sided t-tests OLS regression with and without covariates (see PAP)

attributes.title: Do Representatives really Represent all Constituents equally? A Field Experiment in German State Parliaments

q1.value: Do Representatives really Represent all Constituents equally? A Field Experiment in German State Parliaments

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

registration_responses.q1: Do Representatives really Represent all Constituents equally? A Field Experiment in German State Parliaments
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q5.value: I thank the Bobst Center for Peace and Justice for financial support. Matt Amengual, Alicia Cooperman Daly, Jacob Kopas, Tara Slough, and Madai Urteaga all provided helpful comments to improve the research design.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Political economy models view property rights as the lynchpin to economic development. But many countries with rapid economic growth and large investments in productive infrastructure have weak property protections. Conversely, many countries with stronger property protections struggle to acquire land and build infrastructure projects. Do strong property rights undermine infrastructure construction and, if so, how? This survey experiment examines how the formal structure of property rights affects societal reactions to infrastructure projects through a survey experiment. It also examines whether the party in charge of building infrastructure—the state or private sector—affects societal reactions.

q16.value: As described in the preanalysis plan, I examine whether protections for private property rights lead to the perception of greater bargaining power with respect to the state and, in turn, generate opportunistic behaviors (e.g. demands for greater compensation, holdouts and local public goods). I also look at whether infrastructure built by private firms, rather than state actors, leads individuals to engage in greater opportunistic behavior.

q17.value: I test these hypotheses through a survey experiment in which I vary two factors (1) the structure of property rights and (2) the type of actor developing the project. I then ask a series of outcome questions about bargaining power, compensation, holdouts, local public goods, and electoral behaviors (see preanalysis plan for details).

registration_responses.q5: I thank the Bobst Center for Peace and Justice for financial support. Matt Amengual, Alicia Cooperman Daly, Jacob Kopas, Tara Slough, and Madai Urteaga all provided helpful comments to improve the research design.

attributes.title: Adaptive Experimental Design: Prospects and Applications in Political Science Study 3

q1.value: Adaptive Experimental Design: Prospects and Applications in Political Science Study 3

q2.value: Molly Offer-Westort | Alexander Coppock | Donald Green

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Response to this field provided by the study authors on January 19, 2020: Our goal in this third study is to implement an adaptive algorithm that seeks to maximize the precision of the estimate of the largest treatment effect among a set of treatments. This is different from adaptive algorithms that seek to select the “best” treatment arm. Our setting for this survey experiment is the literature on factual misperceptions. When asked survey questions about factual matters, many subjects give the wrong answer. Partisans often select answers that are more favorable to their party. In this study, we deploy 5 different treatments to see which one decreases misperceptions most.

q16.value: Response to this field provided by the study authors on January 19, 2020: These treatments are (1) asking people to please be accurate; (2) giving people extra time to answer the questions; (3) asking people to please disregard their partisanship when answering; (4) telling people that it’s OK to google the right answers; and (5) offering a chance at a $100 Amazon gift card for each correct answers.

q17.value: Response to this field provided by the study authors on January 19, 2020: Over the course of two weeks, we will invite successive batches of subjects to participate in the experiment. Each day, we will update the probabilities of assignment to each of these five treatments (or control). The probabilities start out even, but the algorithm will adapt over time to assign more subjects to those treatments that appear to be generating larger effects.
